issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
I changed regions couple times (every time a region's changed, it reloads aws all images since I took off 'aws' images filter's). Then the browser locks up and the physical memory for Chrome is at 1GB. After several minutes Chrome came back to operational, but meanwhile killing process is the only option.

When I pulled all aws images from us-east (one-region), Chrome took about 400MB memory.
fields.summary: enumerating all images lock up the browser

comments.body:
[~spark]: Tried reproducing this on Chrome (Mac OS 10.8.5), which showed memory holding steady at 1.2gb when switching regions many times (tried each region).  Not ideal, but the browser did *not* lock up.  What OS are you testing with?

BTW, I added a comment to EUCA-7864 w.r.t. inefficient memory usage using Python's built-in json library.  Seems we could try using simplejson instead of the built-in json library, but that would introduce a new dependency that is probably a bit late to consider for 3.4.0.

/cc [~dkavanagh]
[~kgill] It was mac (latest). I've seen twice last night. Probably OS-level activities (paging), because the process was not responding.

Tested on my MacBook Pro OS X 10.6.8 with 4 GB Memory and ran the proxy on a CentOS QA machine with CLC.

Using the latest Chrome (30.0.1599.101), I did witness some conditions where the browser fails to received the image data from the proxy, resulting in a frozen browser screen, which required refresh, or in some cases, the warning message by the browser that the script  has become unresponsive, which also required refresh of the browser.

Watching the proxy on the CentOS machine via 'top':

7725 root      20   0 3436m 1.7g 4516 S  1.3 22.4   2:21.80 python       

The memory is at 1.7 G range, and it could possibly be continuously increasing. Will check back after an hour or so.

Overall, this is not a single issue that can be just checked away. We will need to come up with more thorough and comprehensive methods to monitor the memory usage of the browser and the proxy.
However, as far the user experience is concerned, the interaction with the AWS's all images has been improved significantly. The delays in interacting with the AWS all images are fairly tolerable.

After about 5 hours of running the proxy, the memory usage has risen up to:

 7725 root      20   0 5681m 3.9g 4512 S  1.3 50.2  11:36.53 python

This behavior of the proxy was observed while testing for the public images on AWS.

However, after 20 hours of running, idling for the most, of the proxy, the total memory usage appears to be flattened at 4.5 GB:

7725 root      20   0 6352m 4.5g 4468 S  0.7 58.0  22:30.94 python
Removed attachments and transferred my proxy memory comments to EUCA-8162 where that's being tracked.

It turns out that when switching the AWS regions and receiving all AWS images causes significant memory leak on the browser -- Chrome in my case.

The initial memory usage of the UI, when logged, on was 7.2 MB. Upon the first viewing of the all AWS images on the region Oregon jumped the memory to be 65.8 MB. When switched over to N.California, it was at 107 MB, then going back to Oregon's image page caused the memory to go up to 155 MB. Repeating back and forth between Oregon and California, the memory size continuously goes up to 210 MB, 257 MB, etc.

Plus, another thing to notice is the number of the objects held by the browser, which was reached to 1.3 million objects with 1.0 million items in arrays. It is known that Firefox is not good at handling such a large size of arrays and strings.

In order to see the memory usage of the UI:

1. Open the UI on Chrome and log into AWS.
2. Open the Developer's tools on Chrome.
3. Select the profiles view on the Developer's tools
4. Perform the initial "Take Heap Snapshot" action to measure the initial memory usage.
5. Go to the image landing page and check out the all AWS images by clicking off the filter.
6. After the images are loaded, go to N.California region and check out the all AWS images in that region
7. Repeat the step 5 and 6 a few times.
8. As repeating the step 7 and 8, check the step 4 and compare the memory usage.
See the attachment for the outcome of the memory profiles of the UI.
[~kyolee], to a lesser extent, I assume this occurs when you have a number of images in the Euca cloud that you are looking at...  is that the case?

Haven't got a chance to test with a Eucalyptus cloud since it takes some time to set up Eucalyptus with a large image data set, which is necessary to detect any significant memory leak on the browser.

The memory leak observation described in the previous comment is noticed while testing on AWS regions. It would be possible that the data path for non-AWS images might be completely different. From my understanding, there are 3 different collections that hold image data in the UI. So, in order to verify if the memory leak condition also exists while pointing to Eucalyptus, we would need to set up a test cloud with a considerably large set of images and repeat the steps above.

After loading Eucalyptus with 40+ images, repeat the steps above, and also discovered the same memory leak issue when navigating the image landing page.

Whenever the image landing page was displayed on the browser, with 43 images, the browser's memory usage would add up between 3 to 8 MB per visit. After 17th visit to the image landing page, the memory was reached at 106 MB.

Re-checked the memory capacity after idling the UI for about 20 mins, and saw the memory was not garbage-collected at all, showing the steady 111 MB memory usage by the UI.

However, the memory was freed when the browser was refreshed, or the user logged out.

After a few days of investigating and researching, it is determined that the memory leak issue on our javascript code is highly complex that it would require more effort that we can handle in this release, the 3.4.1.

In short, the issue is that when going from one region to another, the image data does not get clean up properly and does not get garbage collected. As result, per each region, the browser ends up accumulating 60 MB worth of image data. This mean that if a user visits a different region, the browser is loaded with 120+ MB of image data so that the browser is bounded to slow down substantially or even crash.

The attempted solution for this release was to clear up the cache of the previously visited region. However, it turned that due to the complex in our current UI, this approach was not trivial at all; during this investigation, it was learned that our UI leaked memory at a significant rate throughout every operation. So, attacking this issue itself would demand a whole release cycle to refractor and QA to ensure that no regressions would result from it.

And, regardless of this memory leak issue, it was also confirmed that loading the entire AWS image set on the browser was not a viable approach for the client-side application. The average size of the AWS image set per region is about 60 MB, which is enough to impact the user experience on the browser once it is loaded.

However, there is one quick way to solve the issues above for this release, that is to trigger refresh of the browser when the user selects a different region, which can be done by adding a single line:

location.reload();

By doing so, the memory that was occupied the huge AWS image set and other resources will be freed as the user switches over to a different region.

For the temporal solution for the release of 3.4.1, the pull request has been created:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/pull/240

, which includes one line fix to trigger reload of the browser.
